mods.abstract: This collection features playbills dating back to before Techs first season in 1955-1956. During this time, theatrical productions were primarily held in the Library Auditorium, located is what is now known as the Jere Whitson Building. The Tech Players, officially recognized as Techs Drama Club, staged their first production here. The Backdoor Playhouse was officially named during the 1970-1971 school year. The collection includes programs from the Tech Players, Alpha Psi Omega, and other theater events at the Backdoor Playhouse. It also features programs from productions in the Upper Cumberland region and those attended by Playhouse staff. The programs are organized by decade, with separate folders for National Shakespeare Company programs and Cookeville Arts Council Children's Theatre programs. An "unsorted" folder contains photographs, ticket stubs, theater and opera programs (including those by the Wesley Foundation and Black Student Organization), Tech Players award banquet records, and schedules. Note: Records from 1950s-1970s experienced water damage prior to arriving at the archives, so materials displayed exhibit mold and rust damage.

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Tennessee Technological University. Archives and Special Collections

titleInfo.title: Robert G. Whitfield Photograph Album, Photo-007

mods.abstract: Pier No. 2. From a photograph album by Robert G. Whitfield documents the work of the Nashville Bridge Company on bridges in the Gainsboro and Lebanon areas from 1926 to 1929. The majority of the black and white photographs depict the construction of the Austin Peay Bridge in Jackson County, Tennessee. Other images show the construction of a bridge on the Cumberland River in Lebanon. The collection also includes photographs of camp life during the construction process, featuring the workers involved. Additionally, the album contains photos taken by Whitfield of various other bridges, including those in Gainesboro, Lebanon, Sparta, Martin, Elkton, Halls, and Historic Double Bridges. While many photos focus on the bridge construction, several capture the workers and surrounding areas.

titleInfo.title: Robert G. Whitfield Photograph Album, Photo-100

mods.abstract: Cumberland River, Cofferdam River Pier North Side, Seam on crevice in Bed Rock. From a photograph album by Robert G. Whitfield documents the work of the Nashville Bridge Company on bridges in the Gainsboro and Lebanon areas from 1926 to 1929. The majority of the black and white photographs depict the construction of the Austin Peay Bridge in Jackson County, Tennessee. Other images show the construction of a bridge on the Cumberland River in Lebanon. The collection also includes photographs of camp life during the construction process, featuring the workers involved. Additionally, the album contains photos taken by Whitfield of various other bridges, including those in Gainesboro, Lebanon, Sparta, Martin, Elkton, Halls, and Historic Double Bridges. While many photos focus on the bridge construction, several capture the workers and surrounding areas.

Additionally, the album contains photos taken by Whitfield of various other bridges, including those in Gainesboro, Lebanon, Sparta, Martin, Elkton, Halls, and Historic Double Bridges. While many photos focus on the bridge construction, several capture the workers and surrounding areas.

Verso reads: Old-Time Square Dancing in Kentucky Square dancing is a popular pastime for young and old, as this Renfro Valley Bar Dance, which is broadcast on Saturday nights. Renfro Valley, an old log-cabin settlement, is located on U. S. 25, between Berea and Mt. Vernon, only an hour's drive south of Lexington, Kentucky. Tues Nite ready to cash in [illegible] 200 mi rain make 400 Sorta don' like our motel smells musty. I like the trip so good so far. Mom. Addressed to Carole and Charles Romer.

titleInfo.title: RG 182 Danny Allen Country Music Postcard collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Tennessee Technological University. Archives and Special Collections

titleInfo.title: Stage Scene at Renfro Valley Barn Dance

mods.abstract: In the recto, this post card image shows people on a stage with instruments such as guitars, piano, and microphones spread around the stage. Verso reads: Stage Scene at Renfro Valley Barn dance Renfro Valley, Ky. So far so good no trouble getting through Cincinnati. We had to launch? own speed to 35 and 40 all the way to Daton the wind picked up the snow in places you couldn't see the car in front. I had a bowl of chili and I swear Rene had some of her "Hell" in it hot bar delicious. They expect snow here to-night and zero?. I hauled? for everything hope Betty isn't mad. Holt's here too. Love Tip and Helueas. Addressed to Clinton Diamond.

titleInfo.title: RG 182 Danny Allen Country Music Postcard collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Tennessee Technological University. Archives and Special Collections

mods.abstract: The recto depicts three women holding a different instrument per person, a woman on the left holding a cello, a person on the right holding a guitar, and a person holding a banjo in the middle between the others. They are all in a barn in front of a group of people sitting. Verso reads: The Renfro Valley Barn Dance is not really a dance, but a stage and radio show held each Saturday night in The Big Barn in Renfro Valley. Since its first broadcast back in 1939 WHAS, WLW, and over NBC, CBS, and Mutual Radio Networks. More than three million visitors, coming from each of the 49 states and 7 foreign countries, have paid admission to see Renfro Valley Folks put on the only radio program of its kind presented in a real bar by the actual residents of the surrounding community. Located on U.S. 25 in Renfro Valley, Kentucky. Mom, Aunt Leah, and I Leah played here on my first trip. We were going to Florida. Saw this show.

titleInfo.title: RG 182 Danny Allen Country Music Postcard collection

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Tennessee Technological University. Archives and Special Collections

mods.abstract: There are two sets of this post card, both displaying an older version of the Renfro Valley Country store. Verso reads: Country store - A real old-time country store with antique feature, including the pot-bellied stove, cracker barrel, wooden Indian, clay ball cash register, country post office, etc., etc. Merchandise includes such outdated items as high-button shoes, corsets, yard goods, sun bonnets; together with a line of general merchandise and mountain products. On U.S. 25, Renfro Valley, Ky. Another part of the verso on one of the cards is: Jeff.

Be sure to see him in niversal-International's Western Featurettes, recent releases being "Echo Ranch" and "Hidden Valley Days". Dave's a successful song writer, too, with scores of top-favorite cowboy and hill-Billy songs now being released on MGM Records. If you ask "Red River Dave" about guitars he'll tell you, straight off that with him it's Gretsch Synchromatic exclusively, and has been for years. T.B. shortened his railroading career and he turned to country music. Known best for songs, "Train Whistle Blues", "Down The Old Road To Home" and "Miss. Delta Blues." This photo was used for the marble memorial, now in Highland Park, Meridian, Mississippi.

titleInfo.title: RG 182 Danny Allen Country Music Postcard collection

mods.abstract: The recto for this postcard has Jimmie Skinner leaning on a wheel. Verso has dates and times for events Jimmie Skinner attended. Best wishes always, Jimmie Skinner.

mods.abstract: The image shows Fred Stephens with rope slung over his right shoulder and his right hand grabbing it. Recto reads Fred M. Stephens Composer of "I Just Want Another Cookie, Mother, Please." Written in honor of our Boys in Service Introduced over the air by many radio artists. The recto also reads about who published the work and other information about events of the time. Verso reads, Fred wants to thank his many thousands of friends all over the world who have helped him get so much popularity through many magazines, labor journals, fan clubs, newspapers and personal ways. Fred is rapid heading towards pictures. You, his friends are helping him. Please keep it up. The verso continues more into Fred's life and other information about him.

mods.abstract: Recto shows Jimmie Dolan playing a guitar with his name written on the neck of it. Verso reads Thanks for listenin to the Crescent Jewelers' "Round-Up" time. Crescent Jewelers have a beautiful free gift for all of you. Just bring this card to any one of the four Crescent Stores. Your gift will be held for you only 30 days from the postmark on this card. No purchase necessary .. no obligation. Go to Crescent Jewelers nearest you! Oakland, 1100 Brak day Hayward, 532 First St. Walnut Creek, 1443 Broadway San Francisco (B. T. Brilliant Co.) 2622 Mission St. Get Your free gift--and keep my picture, too. Be with you again tonight, as every night over KYA. Sincerely, Jimmy Dolan. Addressed to Miss Leota Bennett.

Were headed for the Opry tonite (sic) and hope tomorrow I go to Minnesota with the girls. As ever, Dustin (?). Addressed to Mary (?) Case.

titleInfo.title: Six unidentified adult men posed at sign

mods.abstract: Six unidentified adult men posed in front of sign inscribed with: Putnam County Courthouses - After Putnam County was established in 1854, this site was chosen for its courthouse. Fires destroyed the first building soon after it was erected in 1855, a second during the Civil War, and a third in 1899. Construction of this courthouse, James Yeaman, architect, by Scott-Smoot, contractors, was completed in 1900. It was remodeled in 1962-63.

mods.abstract: Unidentified couple holding portrait of unidentified man standing in front of Buck's College sign that reads: Buck's College - Issac Buck let his family to the area from Pennsylvania in 1820. In 1849 he purchased land here and in 1852 he and his son, Jonathan Buck opened Andrew College, commonly called "Buck's College" at this spot. It was the first known secondary school established in Putnam County. It closed during the Civil War and never reopened.

mods.abstract: Putnam County Courthouses sign that reads: Putnam County Courthouses - After Putnam County was established in 1854, this site was chosen for its courthouse. Fires destroyed the first building soon after it was erected in 1855, a second during the Civil War, and a third in 1899. Construction of this courthouse, James Yeaman, architect, by Scott-Smoot, contractors, was completed in 1900. It was remodeled in 1962-63.

titleInfo.title: People with Old Salem Methodist Church sign

mods.abstract: Unidentified group of people with Old Salem Methodist Church sign that reads: Old Salem Methodist Church - South, one mile - Isaac Buck organized this church, one of the oldest in the County, in 1820. Before the Civil War the site was a famous camp meeting ground. When Putnam County was permanently established in 1854, courts met in the old log church, and the militia mustered outside. The present structure was built in 1925.

titleInfo.title: 2025-0001 Dr. Tony Baker Graphic Novel Class comics

mods.abstract:
Students taking Dr. Tony Baker's Fall 2024 Graphic Novel class (ENGL 4650) created Archive Comics Projects by researching primary source documents in Tech's Archives and Special Collections. Students wrote comic scripts and used their artistic skills to compose fiction and nonfiction comics. The student cartoonists used a variety of visual styles to tell a wide range of local, archived-based stories. These stories were digitized and shared in an online exhibit. The archives only holds the digital versions.
In previous Graphic Novel classes, students worked with Kim Winkle's Art 2320 students to illustrate comics. Their work is in published books at the University Archives under Collab-O-Comix.

subject.topic: Alpha Delta Pi Sorority. Epsilon Psi Chapter (Tennessee Technological University)
Tennessee Technological University. Archives and Special Collections

recordInfo.recordContentSource: Tennessee Technological University. Archives and Special Collections

mods.abstract: Tech Times is a newsletter that shares information about events and happenings on the Tennessee Tech campus. The first edition was published in print during the fall 1963 term. It continued in print until January 2003, when it transformed into an email newsletter. The email editions cater to faculty and staff, with a dedicated student edition introduced later. As of 2025, these newsletters are also available online at Tech Times Blog: https://blogs.tntech.edu/techtimes/ Note: There is a significant gap in the Tech Times collection from the years 2007 to 2017. During this period, the newsletter underwent various transitions and updates, which resulted in incomplete archival records.
